contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} The '''Sega VR''' was a [[virtual reality]] headset under development by [[Sega]]. ==Features== The Sega VR was based on an IDEO [[virtual reality]] headset (HMD) with [[Liquid crystal display|LCD]] screens in the visor and stereo headphones.<ref name="Horowitz" /> Inertial sensors in the headset allowed the system to [[tracking system|track]] and react to the movements of the user's head. ==Development== Sega, flush with funds from the success of its [[Mega Drive]] (released as the Sega Genesis in [[North America]]), announced the add-on in 1991.<ref name="Horowitz">{{cite web|last=Horowitz|first=Ken|title=Sega VR: Great Idea or Wishful Thinking?|url=http://www.sega-16.com/feature_page.php?id=5&title=Sega%20VR:%20Great%20Idea%20or%20Wishful%20Thinking?|publisher=Sega-16|date=December 28, 2004|accessdate=21 August 2010|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20100114191355/http://sega-16.com/feature_page.php?id=5&title=Sega%20VR:%20Great%20Idea%20or%20Wishful%20Thinking?|archivedate=2010-01-14}}</ref> Because of development difficulties the Sega VR remained only a prototype, and was never released to the general public. It was last seen at computer shows in 1993<ref name="Horowitz" /> and vanished from release schedules in 1994. Four games were apparently developed for the system, each using 16 [[megabyte|MB]] cartridges that were to be bundled with the headset.<ref name="Horowitz" /> The company claimed to have terminated the project because the virtual reality effect was too realistic. Users might move while wearing the headset and injure themselves.<ref name="Horowitz" /> The limited processing power of the system makes this claim unlikely,{{cn|date=May 2012}} although there were reports of testers developing [[headache]]s and [[motion sickness]].<ref name="Horowitz" /> [[Mark Pesce]], who worked on the Sega VR project, says [[SRI International]], a research institute, warned Sega of the 'hazards of prolonged use'.<ref>{{cite web|last=Robson|first=Wayde|title=WARNING: 3D Video Hazardous to Your Health|url=http://www.audioholics.com/news/editorials/warning-3d-video-hazardous-to-your-health/|publisher=Audioholics|accessdate=14 July 2010}}</ref> ==Legacy== Sega went on to other VR projects for use in arcades and a similar add-on was reported but never seen for the [[Sega Saturn]].<ref name="Horowitz" /><ref>''Gaming Gossip''. [[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]. Issue 70. Pg 54. May 1995.</ref> The project encouraged a brief flurry of other companies to offer VR products.{{cn|date=May 2012}} Sega's chief competitor, [[Nintendo]], would go on to release the ill-fated [[Virtual Boy]] in 1995. The table-top device also brought discomfort after extended play.<ref name="WaPo">Frischling, Bill. "Sideline Play." The Washington Post (1974-Current file): 11. ProQuest Historical Newspapers: The Washington Post (1877-1995). Oct 25 1995.
